Today, large wild fires in Montana, Idaho and elsewhere in the West are blackening forests and forcing residents from their homes.
On an isolated mesa in Colorado, commentator Michelle Nijhuis is wondering whether to pack her suitcases.
Today, as I walk the Western Colorado Mesa where I live, thunder clouds gather in the West, rumbling with afternoon storms.
For me, the heavy clouds were in a fire.
I know that right now, dozens of wildfire stretch over more than a million acres of the Rocky Mountains, threatening homes and neighborhoods I know well.
I'm all too aware that one bolt of lightening could make it my turn.
My fear of fire always starts growing in the spring, when green weeds unfold around the house.
By summer, the grass is dry, the days are heavy and hot, and a persistent haze of smoke makes distant fires feel much too close.
My neighbor doesn't reassure me, yup, he'll occasionally say by way of greeting, this place is going to burn this year.
He's skinny, profane and excitable, and I'm never sure if he's just cultivating an explosive image, or if he really might blow someday.
On summer nights, I walk with my husband along the irrigation canal, its water too far from our house for comfort.
We look across the valley of the hillside that burned 10 years ago; a fire that left two friends with nothing, but the Volkswagen bus they escaped in.
As we walk home, our neighbor's car sometimes rattles by.
I see his silhouette salute us and I scanned the mesa for smoke.

This, remember, was 10 years after the US had abolished public hanging.

The second case that Guilloux concentrates on in a novel he later wrote about his experience was the case of a white Ranger officer who killed a French Resistance fighter in a bar--killed him, you know, right to his face.

He was the official interpreter in these courts-martial.
